Text: amendment on the clause, but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: clause itself.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: O n the point of order,-

Speaker: NA
Text: I submit that i f the contention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is agreed to, the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee will be placed in an absurd posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I cannot understand the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House contending that the motion

Speaker: NA
Text: " That the question be now p u t " covers,

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the amendment, but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: original question, " That the clause be

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to." The question " That the

Speaker: NA
Text: question be now p u t " covers only the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment immediately before the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee. I f that were not so, then the

Speaker: NA
Text: closure having been applied as soon as-

Speaker: NA
Text: an amendment to" a clause had been sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted, no other amendment, however

Speaker: NA
Text: important, could be submitted.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE
Text: Tha t is what the stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing order provides.

Speaker: Mr FENTON
Text: Th e Chairman has

Speaker: NA
Text: ruled that clause 2 is now open for dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion. The only way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister or any other member can

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed to upset that ruling is to move

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Chairman's ruling be disagreed

Speaker: NA
Text: with. I understand that you, Mr Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, now rule that clause 2 is open for

Speaker: NA
Text: debate.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Le t me call the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the committee to a ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: given on this point by Mr Speaker John-

Speaker: NA
Text: son on the 20th September, 1922-

Speaker: NA
Text: When a motion has been agreed to, "That

Speaker: NA
Text: the question be now put," it embraces not only

Speaker: NA
Text: any amendment before the Chair, but all steps

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to bring tlie main question to a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion. That .is provided for in the Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders; and, for that reason, honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers are now called upon to vote upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: question, " That the Bill be now read a third

Speaker: NA
Text: time."

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: D o I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: in consequence of a bad ruling given

Speaker: NA
Text: by an ex-Speaker you now propose to go

Speaker: NA
Text: back on your own ruling?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: I .now rule that

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 2 must be put. forthwith with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out debate.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: I am afraid that we

Speaker: NA
Text: must take action to upset that ruling.

Speaker: NA
Text: I place no reliance upon any ruling by

Speaker: NA
Text: the former Speaker, Sir Elliot Johnson.

Speaker: NA
Text: He decided, on occasions, that the Stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Orders were adequate, and when they

Speaker: NA
Text: were not adequate he relied upon his own

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment. He referred to May, when i t

Speaker: NA
Text: suited him so to do, and his decisions were

Speaker: NA
Text: of no value. We must refer this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: to the - Speaker, -so that we may have a

Speaker: NA
Text: definite decision.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE
Text: I suggest that i f the Act-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Leader of the Opposition disagrees

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Chairman's ruline. he must sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mit his objection i n writing, and the mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter niust be decided forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr . ANSTEY - I did not object to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman's original r u l i n g ; I accepted i t .

Speaker: NA
Text: The objection came from the Prime M i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: ister, and he should have taken the course

Speaker: NA
Text: that he now suggests I should take.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE
Text: I accept the Chairman's

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: Th e Prime Minister ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cepts i t when i t suits him.

Speaker: Mr BOWDEN
Text: I rise to a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. The House having resolved that

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 2 be now put, i t must be put and

Speaker: NA
Text: voted 'upon without debate. A motion for

Speaker: NA
Text: dissent cannot be interposed at this stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause agreed to.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: I now propose to move

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Chairman's ruling be dissented

Speaker: NA
Text: from.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: I cannot accept

Speaker: NA
Text: the motion.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: Yo u are very tyrannical.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Standing Orders you must

Speaker: NA
Text: accept a motion for dissent.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Richmond has the floor.

Speaker: Mr FENTON
Text: I rise to a point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is competent for an honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: to move dissent from the ruling of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman at any time, and upon the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent being submitted i n writing, i t must

Speaker: NA
Text: be decided by the committee. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: closure had been applied, clause 2 had to

Speaker: NA
Text: be put to the committee forthwith, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Acting Leader of the Opposition was

Speaker: NA
Text: not permitted to interpose a motion for

Speaker: NA
Text: dissent. A t the earliest subsequent op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity he seeks to submit'his motion,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I contend, sir, that you must accept

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: T h e dissent by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Bourke relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: my ruling upon clause 2, which has al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready been put and passed; therefore, any

Speaker: NA
Text: motion of dissent relating to that clause

Speaker: NA
Text: is out of order.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE
Text: Th e right of honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members to move dissent from a Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man's ruling i n certain circumstances is

Speaker: NA
Text: involved i n the point of order raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Maribyrnong.

Speaker: NA
Text: You, sir, would not permit the Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition to submit his

Speaker: NA
Text: dissent u n t i l clause 2 had been put, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that question having been disposed of, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member is now entitled to move

Speaker: NA
Text: to dissent from your ruling. As an i m -

Speaker: NA
Text: portant question of procedure is involved,

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that we might adopt a course

Speaker: NA
Text: for which there is precedent, namely, to

Speaker: NA
Text: refer the matter to the Speaker.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: I propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt the suggestion of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, and refer the matter to the Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: Th e Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that a motion for dissent must be

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted to the committee.

Speaker: Mr BOWDEN
Text: Th e Chairman has the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to refer the matter to the Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: if he eo desires.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: A motion to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent may be decided by the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: without reference to the Speaker. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, I shall accept the motion of the Act-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Leader of the Opposition to dissent

Speaker: NA
Text: from my ruling i f he will state i n writing

Speaker: NA
Text: the reason for his objection.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the ruling of the Chairman be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented from.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member must submit the grounds on which

Speaker: NA
Text: he dissents from my ruling .

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: I do so. I object to the

Speaker: NA
Text: doubly conflicting rulings of the Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: factory' respectively mean, in relation to any

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I have reduced the quantity of

Speaker: NA
Text: cheese mentioned to26 tons, because

Speaker: NA
Text: cheese factories are generally established

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tories are erected. A cheese factory can

Text: lishment of a butter factory.

Text: ber of small factories i n Victoria produc-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: put, should be excluded from the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: -plentiful, and i t did not tur n out, annu-

Speaker: NA
Text: or ally, more than about 20 tons of butter,

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing most of which was exported.

Text: Flinders-Prim e Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 4-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1.) For the purposes of this act there shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be a Dairy Produce Control Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2.) The board shall consist of-

Speaker: NA
Text: . (a) one member (in this act referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: as " the Government representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: t i v e " ) who shall be appointed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General as the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentative of the Commonwealth Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) one representative of each state

Speaker: NA
Text: elected by the boards of directors

Speaker: NA
Text: of co-operative butter and cheese

Speaker: NA
Text: factories in that state;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) two representatives elected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: boards of directors of proprietary

Speaker: NA
Text: butter and cheese factories; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) ong member appointed by the Gover-

Speaker: NA
Text: nor-General as the representative of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons engaged as sellers of dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: produce out of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: whether as agents or on their own

Speaker: NA
Text: account.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3.) The Governor-General shall not ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: point, as the Government representative, any

Speaker: NA
Text: person who has submitted himself for, and

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to secure, election by the producers as

Speaker: NA
Text: a member of the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4.) The member appointed as the 'Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment representative shall hold office during

Speaker: NA
Text: the pleasure of tlie Governor-General.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5.) The election of representatives in pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: suance of paragraphs (6) and (c) of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: section (2.) of this section shall .be carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out -in such manner as 'is prescribed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6.) Tlie member appointed in pursuance of

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph (d) of sub-section (2.) of this

Speaker: NA
Text: section shall be appointed for a -term of two

Speaker: NA
Text: years, but may be removed from office 'by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General .upon the recommendation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7.) Elected members of the board shall

Speaker: NA
Text: hold office for a period of two years and shall

Speaker: NA
Text: bo eligible for re-election:

Speaker: NA
Text: Provided "that .an 'ejected menrber may be

Speaker: NA
Text: removed from office by the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: on the recommendation of the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8.) On tlie death, resignation, or removal

Speaker: NA
Text: from office of an elected member of the board,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General may, ou the -recomimen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation of the board, appoint a person to hold

Speaker: NA
Text: the vacant office for the residue of the term

Speaker: NA
Text: of -the elected member.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9.) The powers conferred on the board by

Speaker: NA
Text: this act shall not ibe affected by reason .only

Speaker: NA
Text: of there being & vacancy in -the membership

Speaker: NA
Text: thereof.

Text: proposed by the Government is not accep-

Text: table to Queensland, which produces

Text: only one .representative is appointed to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, New South Wales, and Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, will be very strong on the business

Text: operative control, and honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers should support the views that 1

Text: have expressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: consider that the board should be com-

Text: Richmond) [10.2] -

Text: Although I agree w i th the proposal of

Text: the honorable member for Capricornia

Text: farmer has not this advantage. I t will

Text: be very difficult, indeed, to keep a roll

Text: of the butter producers of Australia up

Text: penses of a Commonwealth-wide election

Text: w i ll be out of all proportion to the ad-

Text: vantages of such a course. The per-

Text: - I sonnel of the board is the .crux of the

Text: fore, I cannot support i t . When i t

Text: Flinders-Prim e Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and Minister f o r External Affairs )

Speaker: NA
Text: [ 1 0 . 9 ] - I cannot accept the amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has given a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of consideration to this question. The

Speaker: NA
Text: object, in f r a m i ng this clause, was to

Text: get the numbers within the smallest pos-

Text: sible compass. We felt that an un-

Text: wieldy board would not prove so efficient

Speaker: NA

Text: drafted, the Government has received re-

Text: presentations f r o m producers urging that

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of representatives of co-opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive butter and cheese factories be i n -

Text: creased. I n support of this claim i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out that there are three great

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting states, and three which, at

Speaker: NA
Text: present, export but very little. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: provides that each of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shall have equal representation on

Speaker: NA
Text: the board. The Government believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that greater confidence will be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: the producers i f the representation is i

Speaker: NA
Text: creased to embrace an additional mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber from each of the states of Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. New South Wales, and. Victoria, as

Text: proposed by the amendment moved by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Capricornia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is therefore prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that portion of the amendment,

Speaker: NA
Text: but not the proposal that the board shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be elected by the producers. Although

Text: this may be a very admirable and demo-

Text: cratic principle, yet i t is faced with grave

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties, because the representative men

Text: in the industry would possibly be un-

Text: known to the producers i n the different

Text: districts. The directors of the co-opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive companies are elected by the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operators in the different districts, and-

Text: consequently directly represent the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers; therefore the election, although

Text: confined to the directors, would really be

Text: controlled by the producers themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The directors would be i n a better posi-

Text: tion to know the relative merits of the

Speaker: NA
Text: different persons applying for appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the board, and consequently the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government feels that i t is much more

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable that, the election should be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fined to them. The Government is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to accept the amendment i n so far

Speaker: NA
Text: as i t contemplates an increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: representation of New South Wales, Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, and Queensland, but not the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal for the election to be held by the

Speaker: NA
Text: producers themselves. This will prac-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: be moved by the honorable member for

Text: cornia withdraw paragraph 6 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Richmond to insert his pro-

Text: and determining authority respecting the

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: Gwydir) [10.17].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I disagree both with the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal and with the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: moved by the honorable member for Cap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ricomia. This Government, since i t has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in office, has done nothing but ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: point expensive and unwieldy boards.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t now proposes to establish another.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even if this proposal were agreed to, i t

Speaker: NA
Text: would be impossible to obtain in the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth the requisite number of dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: experts to be appointed to the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the first twelve months the opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the board would largely consist of

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries respecting possible markets. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, when introducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, referred to the New Zealand act, on

Speaker: NA
Text: which he said the bill was in many re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spects modelled. The New Zealand board

Speaker: NA
Text: was established either early this year or

Speaker: NA
Text: late last year, and in respect of its opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion the following paragraph, headed

Speaker: NA
Text: " Policy not fixed; delegation to Europe,"

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared in the New Zealand Dairyman,

Speaker: NA
Text: dated the 20th February, 1924: -

Speaker: NA
Text: The most important matter discussed at the

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of this board was the future policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: and after mature consideration it was unani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously decided that before any definite policy

Speaker: NA
Text: could be adopted very fall and complete inves-

Speaker: NA
Text: tigation of the markets of Canada, United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America, and Europe should be made

Speaker: NA
Text: by a delegation consisting of three members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the board. The personnel of the delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: would be decided at the next meeting, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: itinerary would be fixed, and a schedule be

Speaker: NA
Text: pared of matters requiring particular investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation. The delegation obviously could not get

Speaker: NA
Text: through the work and return to New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: before October, and it was therefore doubtful

Speaker: NA
Text: whether any form of control would be exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cised over butter and its export during the

Speaker: NA
Text: next season.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the experience of New Zealand.

Speaker: NA
Text: A board of control was appointed, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: held a meeting in February, 1924.

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be no control over the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: season's production, because the board has

Speaker: NA
Text: not investigated possible markets. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: ridiculous to suggest that twelve members

Speaker: NA
Text: should be appointed to a board of control,

Speaker: NA
Text: which during the next twelve months can

Speaker: NA
Text: do nothing else than investigate overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: markets. I t would be much preferable to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a small competent board.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment of a small executive.

Text: T h e n appoint

Speaker: NA
Text: the executive, and not the board. Suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful businesses are conducted, not

Speaker: NA
Text: by a large number . of managers,

Speaker: NA
Text: but. by a few capable men.

Speaker: NA
Text: i t may be possible to secure the ser-

Text: vices of three or of five first-rate men

Text: to control the industry, i f a large number

Speaker: NA
Text: of members are appointed to the board

Text: there will be some amongst them who are

Speaker: NA
Text: not experts, or even first class men i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: business. I was surprised to hear the

Text: pared to allow the producers to elect the

Text: members of the board. He is prepared

Text: fuse to trust the dairy farmers, with the

Text: election of the members of this board

Speaker: NA
Text: which w i l l haveautocratic powers i n the

Text: disposition of their produce. The board

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to mortgage i t , to insure i t ,

Text: or not, as i t thinks fit, and to sell i t where,

Text: when, or for what price i t pleases. I t is

Text: opposed to all the principles of democracy

Text: ducing butter to say who shall be mem-

Text: bers of the board appointed to control its

Text: in Queensland and the man producing

Text: butter i n New South Wales, Victoria, or

Text: South Australia? The proposals made

Text: would keep alive state jealousies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very glad that the Prime Minister

Text: ( Mr Bruce) has accepted the amend-

Text: ment. Telegrams that I have received

Text: may he of interest to honorable members.

Text: One f r o m Mr Clifford, General Manager

Text: of the N o r t h Coast Co-operative Com-

Text: pany, Byron Bay, reads-

Text: alter representation of states on Export Con-

Text: trol Board. As large co-operative manufac-

Text: turers, with 2,500 suppliers, and an output

Text: urge you to give tlie representation asked for

Text: in the scheme placed before you by the inter-

Text: state conference."

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: Have wired the Prime Minister as follows:-

Text: " Our association, representing 21 butter fac-

Text: tories, Northern Rivers, New South Wales,

Text: with 5,000 suppliers and turn-over 20,000 tons

Text: butter annually, protest against inadequate

Text: suggested, and crave your adherence to pre-

Text: vious decision interstate conference regarding

Text: representation on board to be elected in re-

Text: spect to dairying export control."

Text: I n addition, I have received the follow-

Text: ing telegram f r o m Mr Dunlop, Primary

Text: Producers' Union, Sydney-

Text: board agreed upon at interstate conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: Urge two representatives for each three large

Text: producing states.

Text: PAIRS. I suggest to the Prime Minister that

Text: when the rules governing the election of

Text: Bourke) [11.19] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: have listened w i th interest to the remark*

Text: of the honorable member f o r Richmondj

Speaker: NA
Text: and I f a i l to understand the amendment

Text: that he has moved. H i s arguments, how-

Text: ever, were apparently so effective that

Text: this committee his reasons f o r doing so.

Text: M t . BRUCE - I gave the reasons earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: in the debate.

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: T h e n they must have

Speaker: NA
Text: been obscured by the arguments that

Speaker: NA
Text: were subsequently raised by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member f o r Richmond. Having

Speaker: NA
Text: convinced the Prime Minister, " under the

Speaker: NA
Text: lap " of the House, that the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: should be accepted, the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber f o r Richmond was not satisfied w i t h

Speaker: NA
Text: his victory. He had to make a long

Speaker: NA
Text: speech to expedite the passage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. I feel that I shall be acting

Speaker: NA
Text: i n the interests of the honorable member,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Byron Bay district i n particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of the country generally, i f I empha-

Speaker: NA
Text: size the importance of the amendment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that its purpose is to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: certain producers to be given two repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives. I f any deduction can be drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: fro m the speech just made by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Richmond, i t is that he-

Speaker: NA
Text: is not prepared to give the producers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia any representation on the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: H e is not taking a broad, national view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter, but is still limited to the nar-

Speaker: NA
Text: row, parochial state outlook. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: 154,000 dairy producers i n Australia, of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom 87 per cent, are i n Victoria, New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, and Queensland, the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: for those three states being, 42,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: 56,000, and 35,000 respectively. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: great speech which the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: made yesterday at the Nationalist confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence he stressed the necessity for demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cratizing the Nationalist party. Accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to him, the Nationalist party was dy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, and the only thing that could save.

Speaker: NA
Text: its life wasdemocratization. He is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeding to democratize it by accepting an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to this clause which will deny

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairy producers any representation on

Speaker: NA
Text: the board. The men who work the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farms and are the backbone of the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, are to have no voice in the disposal

Speaker: NA
Text: of their products.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr R. GBEEN -Wha t i circus !

Speaker: Mr ANSTEY
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber is a good judge of circuses. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing but his verbosity that has brought

Speaker: NA
Text: me to my feet, and I can assure him that

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall be just as exuberant in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: hours of the morning as I am now. I

Speaker: NA
Text: submit that the representation 'on the

Speaker: NA
Text: board will be on an altogether inequitable

Speaker: NA
Text: basis i f the amendment is agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia, South Australia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania export very little dairy produce,

Speaker: NA
Text: and yet they are to be given substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: representation on the board. Ninety per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, of the dairy produce exported from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia goes from Victoria, New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, and Queensland. I cannot under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand how the Prime Minister can har-

Speaker: NA
Text: monize his recently expressed views on fhe

Speaker: NA
Text: democratizing of the Nationalist party

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proposed representation en the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy export control board. Neither he

Speaker: NA
Text: nor the honorable member for Richmond

Speaker: NA
Text: is taking a broad national view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject. The Prime Minister, like myself,

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes to save this country from the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremes of reactionary conservatism and

Speaker: NA
Text: of reactionary communism. I intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: read, for honorable members' information,

Speaker: NA
Text: extracts from what may be regarded as a,

Speaker: NA
Text: confidential communication addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerang Co-operative Butter Factory,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is hostile to the measure, as, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed, the Prime Minister is. He does not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in i t in a broad national sense,

Speaker: NA
Text: only because he has to comply with the

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes of the blackmailers. We all appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate the position in which the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister finds himself. Do we not see

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable members for Richmond,

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper, and New England holding him

Speaker: NA
Text: up and demanding blackmail? The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is inundated with communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from an i*arfs of the country object-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the bill. Of course, he does not

Speaker: NA
Text: take us into his confidence, and, there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, I wish to place on record this in-

Speaker: NA
Text: teresting statement from the Kerang Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative Butter Factory-

Speaker: NA
Text: We wired to you this afternoon as follows

Speaker: NA
Text: - " We respectfully and emphatically protest

Speaker: NA
Text: against giving control of our business to any

Speaker: NA
Text: board. We desire freedom to sell our surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: at f.o.b. prices."

Speaker: NA
Text: How scandalous i t is that healthy com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition should be eliminated by an act

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government! We could under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the wild hare-brained and long-

Speaker: NA
Text: haired revolutionary " scoundrels " on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the committee desiring to elimi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate public competition, but surely never

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government! Nevertheless, that is-

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Government is doing in this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers are driven, not by their prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples, but by the necessities of the hour,

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have to look for their support

Speaker: NA
Text: not to honorable members behind them,

Speaker: NA
Text: but to honorable 'members in the corner,

Speaker: NA
Text: who take advantage of the fact that they

Speaker: NA
Text: hold the balance of power, and, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: language of the Prime Minister, levy this-

Speaker: NA
Text: specious blackmail upon the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I object to the proposal of the honorable-

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Richmond, and to the accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of i t by the Prime Minister. This

Speaker: NA
Text: great industry should not be controlled by

Speaker: NA
Text: a board representative of the areas within

Speaker: NA
Text: state boundaries; its economic interests-

Speaker: NA
Text: should be studied. The Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister has denounced the Russian-

Speaker: NA
Text: sovietism. What is its aim? . Its pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose, first of all, is to ensure economic, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stead of political, control of industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the basis of the Russian revolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I t swept away the rule of great

Speaker: NA
Text: industries by politicians, and substituted

Speaker: NA
Text: for it rule by experts. This bill makes a

Speaker: NA
Text: concession to that principle, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment of the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond will have the effect of taking

Speaker: NA
Text: the control of the industry away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: real producers of the commodity and plac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing i t in the hands of the actual exporters-.

Text: I call attention to the

Text: arrangement. Last year the factory made

Speaker: NA

Text: : than it did out of the process of consign-

Text: ing. As a result, large numbers of dairy

Text: without speculating on the London mar-

Text: ket. Under the b i l l the f.o.b. arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: For the three years 1912, 1-913, 1914, the

Speaker: NA
Text: average production of butter in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was 193,407,000 lb., the average value for

Speaker: NA
Text: these: three years being £9,299,000.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: 1922, the average production was

Speaker: NA
Text: 236,716,000 lb.., the average value, for

Speaker: NA
Text: these' three years being £2.0,237,000..

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the 1912 -14 period i t will be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: that the production of butter has. in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased 22 per cent., and the value

Speaker: NA
Text: by 120 per cent. I n view of the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: board.. I commend the honorable member

Speaker: Mr FENTON
Text: Maribyrnong) [4.7 a.m.]

Speaker: NA
Text: - I do not think the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gwydir ( Mr Cunningham) need have

Speaker: NA
Text: any apprehension about the Eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. I t is already well established, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we hold from 90 per cent, to 95 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: of it.

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: I was referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: the illegitimate traders who might use

Speaker: NA
Text: that avenue to defeat the objects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: Mr FENTON
Text: I doubt i f that would

Speaker: NA
Text: be possible, for the simple reason that, for

Speaker: NA
Text: our European export trade we use refrige-

Speaker: NA
Text: rator space, and the butter is put up i n

Speaker: NA
Text: 56-lb. boxes, whereas for the Eastern trade

Speaker: NA
Text: it is put up in tins or cartons. That trade

Speaker: NA
Text: is at our door, so to speak. I t belongs

Speaker: NA
Text: naturally to the Australian producers, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be most regrettable i f anything

Speaker: NA
Text: was done to hamper it. I f only 1 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, of the people of China consumed our

Speaker: NA
Text: butter and our fruit we should have an

Speaker: NA
Text: immense market, and should not need to

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble about the European trade at all.

Speaker: Mr R GREEN
Text: Richmond) [4.10

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m.]-Th e objections which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by myself and other honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members have been to the principle

Speaker: NA
Text: of the amendment; not with regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to any section of the export

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. I agree with the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: the able member for Maribyrnong that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eastern trade naturally belongs to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, and that, therefore, i t may be left

Speaker: NA
Text: out of consideration. But the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: which I foreshadowed will give power to

Speaker: NA
Text: the board to take certain action i f the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eastern trade channel is being used to

Speaker: NA
Text: defeat the object of this bill. The clauses

Speaker: NA
Text: with which we are now dealing are the

Speaker: NA
Text: crux of the measure. I was very disap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed with the Prime Minister's ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: planation of these provisions. The board

Speaker: NA
Text: will exercise no control over production

Speaker: NA
Text: intended for consumption in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: but i f producers desire to export they

Speaker: NA
Text: must hand their product over to it .

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister did not answer satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factorily the supposititious case which I

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted of butter shipped ostensibly to

Speaker: NA
Text: South Africa, but intended really for

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain. He contented himself with

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that, i f necessary, an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with a contingency of that nature

Speaker: NA
Text: could be inserted in another place. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill originated in this House, and surely

Speaker: NA
Text: the collective wisdom of this chamber,

Speaker: NA
Text: with its 76 members, is greater than that

Speaker: NA
Text: of another place which has only 36

Speaker: NA
Text: members.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member is not i n order in

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to the Senate.

Speaker: Mr R GREEN
Text: Th e Minister is to

Speaker: NA
Text: have f u ll control of all butter exported

Speaker: NA
Text: to the European market, but not of butter

Speaker: NA
Text: exported "to South Africa, America, or

Speaker: NA
Text: to the East. I t is only right that the

Speaker: NA
Text: producers should have some say in the

Speaker: NA
Text: disposal of a product in which they are

Speaker: NA
Text: vitally interested, and I regret that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government propose to deal only with

Speaker: NA
Text: the control of butter for export. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is to have f u l l control, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of' the bill will be defeated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The board should have control, but if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will accept an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the effect that the Minister, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendation of the" board, can

Speaker: NA
Text: either issue or revoke licences, I shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to withdraw my amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: providing for control by the board. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Kooyong pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out the danger of giving f u l l control of

Speaker: NA
Text: the export of butter to the Minister. I

Speaker: NA
Text: interviewed another member of the legal

Speaker: NA
Text: profession last evening, and he agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the honorable member for Kooyong,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the board would practically have no

Speaker: NA
Text: power i f the control were given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. I n such a case there would

Speaker: NA
Text: be no possibility of the provisions of this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill conflicting with those of the Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. But i f the Minister could act only

Speaker: NA
Text: on the recommendation of the board, any

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt by him to contravene the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions of the bill Avould be checked by the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the Customs Act. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: in its present form leaves too much to

Speaker: NA
Text: political control. I appeal to the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister not to limit the control of export to

Speaker: NA
Text: the European market. I should not ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject to an exemption in the case of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eastern trade, because i t has its peculiari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. ,

Speaker: Mr GABB
Text: Angas) [4.25 a.m.] -Thi s

Speaker: NA
Text: is the fourth occasion on which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavoured to speak on this subject. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party cannot be accused of hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing attempted to waste the time of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee in discussing clauses 14 to 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have now an illustration of hasty

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, and the blame rests absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Government and its supporters. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister wishes to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: fiim in Melbourne that sends canned

Speaker: NA
Text: butter to the East, there is nothing in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to prevent the Minister from

Speaker: NA
Text: granting a licence to that firm

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue its operations. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no provision in the bill preventr

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister from issuing a licence to

Speaker: NA
Text: such a firm. But to get over the diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty the Prime Minister has moved to

Speaker: NA
Text: insert in the clause two words "to

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe." The bill originally provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for the control of butter exports to the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole world; but, i f the amendment is

Speaker: NA
Text: carried, all but European countries will be

Speaker: NA
Text: exempted from its provisions. The pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of dummying has been mentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is nothing in the bill to prevent a

Speaker: NA
Text: purfirm from obtaining a licence to export,

Speaker: NA
Text: placing butter in 56-lb. boxes in the cool-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing chamber of a vessel calling at

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo, and consigning i t to some one

Speaker: NA
Text: there who would not take one box out,

Speaker: NA
Text: but simply re-consign i t to London, in

Speaker: NA
Text: that mariner breaking down the control

Speaker: NA
Text: system that "we are now trying to estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish. The Prime Minister stated that, i f

Speaker: NA
Text: he" found that there was any danger in

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposal, it would be remedied in an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other place.' But we are here, not to pass

Speaker: NA
Text: slap-dash legislation to be rectified in an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other place, but to give f u l l consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: to all matters that come before us. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment should not have been moved

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: certain that it would not have a damaging

Speaker: NA
Text: effect upon the export of butter. He also

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: - I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be recommitted for the recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration of clause 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: My reason for doing this, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: is that during your absence through the

Speaker: NA
Text: night we have had a most dreadful time

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber. I can only express the

Speaker: NA
Text: hope thab the groans of anguish that rose

Speaker: NA
Text: have not disturbed you in your sleep. Dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this .troublous time we have had no op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to consider clause 21. That

Speaker: NA
Text: clause does not stand alone in that respect,

Speaker: NA
Text: because there were others, but i t comes

Speaker: NA
Text: under special notice, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: peculiar construction of the bill. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Bruce) moved for

Speaker: NA
Text: the application of an instrument, known

Speaker: NA
Text: as the "guillotine," by which means the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government chopped off a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses of the bill ending at clause 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: As might be expected, in operating such

Speaker: NA
Text: a dangerous weapon, no trouble was taken

Speaker: NA
Text: to ascertain whether there was any con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion between clause 21 and the clause

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately following, which would have

Speaker: NA
Text: made it more appropriate to drop the

Speaker: NA
Text: guillotine at clause 20, so that clauses 21

Speaker: NA
Text: and 22 might be considered in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: junction. As a matter of fact, these two

Speaker: NA
Text: NOBS. clauses are wedded; yet they were merci-'

Speaker: NA
Text: lessly divorced by the motion 'submitted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister. I t is painful for

Speaker: NA
Text: me to have to tell you, Mr Speaker, that

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members on the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: side were nearly all asleep, but honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: PATES. members of the Opposition considered

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 22, and in i t found references to

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of expenses and other

Speaker: NA
Text: charges incurred by the board. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: happily there was nothing before us to

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate how those expenses and other

Speaker: NA
Text: charges were to be met. We were not per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted to consider clause 21, in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary provision is made, and I am now

Speaker: NA
Text: asking that even at this early hour in the

Speaker: NA
Text: day opportunity should be afforded to us

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider it. Clause 21 provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1.) There shall be a Dairy Produce Export

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund into which shall be paid out of the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidated Revenue Fund, which is hereby ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriated accordingly, all moneys received by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Collector of Customs under the Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Produce Export Charges Act 1924.

Speaker: Mr FENTON
Text: U n f o r t u n a t e l y there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no such act i n existence.

Speaker: Mr BRENNAN
Text: T h a t act is, as

Speaker: NA
Text: lawyers say, i n v e n t r e sa m i r e , t h a t is,

Speaker: NA
Text: i t is i n the pre-natal stage. T h e clause

Speaker: NA
Text: also provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: (2.) Where any .account referred to in section

Speaker: NA
Text: twenty-three of this act is opened, payment

Speaker: NA
Text: into that account of the moneys mentioned i n

Speaker: NA
Text: the last preceding section shall be held to be

Speaker: NA
Text: payment into the fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: I trust, sir, that you, from your exalted

Speaker: NA
Text: position, will extol my moderation. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not asking for much when I seek merely

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommittal of clause 21. I should

Speaker: NA
Text: very much like the Government to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent to the recommittal of all bhe clauses

Speaker: NA
Text: which honorable members have been pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vented from discussing; and in a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit of penitence, having the facts now

Speaker: NA
Text: before them, and the inadequacy of op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity exemplified to them by experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, Ministers might very well consent to

Speaker: NA
Text: do even that. However,. I shall be satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied for the moment with small favours,

Speaker: NA
Text: and i f the Government will consent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommittal of clause 21 I do not say that

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall 'be for ever grateful to them, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall recognize i t as a belated act of

Speaker: NA
Text: very moderate and unexpected decency on

Speaker: NA
Text: their part. I t is curious that, in the course

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debate in committee, clause 21,

Speaker: NA
Text: linked "up with clause 22, was shown by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Acting Leader of the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: be closely interwoven with clause 23, which

Speaker: NA
Text: also refers to the moneys held i n the same

Speaker: NA
Text: fund . I f you, Mr Speaker, had heard

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member f o r Bourke skil-

Speaker: NA
Text: f u l ly expounding his argument, you

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the more ready to agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is reason f o r the re--

Speaker: NA
Text: committal of the clause. W e have

Speaker: NA
Text: gathered from hearsay that the dairy pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce f u n d is to be created by a leivy im

Speaker: NA
Text: posed on the whole of the dairying i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry i n the interests of certain highly-

Speaker: NA
Text: paid individuals, and. we regard the f u n

Speaker: NA
Text: and the method by which i t is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: created, with the utmost suspicion. By a

Speaker: NA
Text: careful calculation, the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: proved that no less than £50,000 per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum will be exacted from the already

Speaker: NA
Text: over-taxed. persons who carry on the i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry. No information has been given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the committee, and no information is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to be vouchsafed to the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: as to how the money is to be expended.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know how i t is to be levied, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: know the merciless Government whose i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: struments are to extract i t , but the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has given no indication that he

Speaker: NA
Text: is agreeable to the recommittal of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: clause. Therefore, I hardly Enow what

Speaker: NA
Text: to say.

Speaker: NA

Text: minor matters, at the beginning of each

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: object i n view. They desired, not to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: place i n the near future, as they con-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
